Fig. 1 FTIR spectra of (a) DBU; (b) Imidazole; (c) 1-methylimidazole; (d) 2-methylimidazole; (e) [DBUH]+[Im]− IL; (f) [DBUH]+[1-MIm]− IL; (g) [DBUH]+[2-MIm]− IL. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 1H NMR spectra of 2-methylimidazole, DBU and [DBUH]+[2-MIm]−. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Proposed mechanism for the synthesis of DHPMs using [DBUH]+[2-Mim]− Ils protic ionic liquids. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) Optimized Structure of [DBUH]+[2-MIm]− IL; (b) HOMO for IL showing the availability of electrons on [2-MIm]−; (c) LUMO for IL showing un-occupied orbitals largely concentrated on [DBUH]+. Research and Development Molekule Inc 3802 Spectrum BLVD Tampa Florida 33612 USA In present work, the application of a novel set of 1,8-Diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene (DBU) and methylimidazole (MIm) coupled ionic liquids (ILs) in the Biginelli reaction has been investigated. In the modified Biginelli reaction, cinnamaldehyde, urea, and 1,3-diketone condensed in the presence of 10 mol% of the DBU-MIm coupled IL catalyst at 90 °C to afford dihydropyrimidinones in high to excellent yields in 45 min. Additionally, the effect of temperature, catalytic amount, and solvent has also been unfolded. The reaction has been found to the follow iminium ion mechanism and the synergic role played by the [DBUH]+ and [MIm]− moieties has been established by DFT calculations. The easy post-procedure recovery and reusability of the DBU-MIm IL catalysts make the present protocol of Biginelli synthesis simple, benign and reproducible. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biginelli Dihydropyrimidines DBU Synergic catalysis Coupled ionic liquids Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction The development of more sustainable catalytic processes is critical in modern chemistry. Ionic liquids (ILs) offer a means of achieving this goal to a greater extent as they have been reported to catalyze a number of organic transformations [1–3] under much milder reaction conditions than those described in their absence. The ILs have been claimed to be the best alternative to conventional organic solvents in terms of toxicity, volatility, thermal stability, and environmental concerns [4]. Besides this, the usage of IL catalysts in the organic transformations has resulted in higher percentages of selectivity and yield. Imidazole-derived ILs, for example, have been investigated for their catalytic behavior in numerous organic transformations, including condensation reactions [5,6], cycloadditions [7], coupling reactions [8,9], and multicomponent reactions (MCRs) [10–12]. In all these reactions, the product was achieved in much higher yields, with high selectivity and enantioselectivity. In some cases, the presence of acidic proton in imidazolidinium (Im) moiety flanked by two nitrogen atoms enhanced the electrophilic character of the substrate and thus catalyzed the reactions [13]. Others have reported that Im-derived ILs stimulate product formation by lowering the activation energy barrier by stabilizing polar intermediates via H-bonding interactions or by enhancing the stability of metal catalysts against leaching [14]. The 1,8-Diazabicyclo(5.4.0) undec-7-ene (DBU) is a super base that has been used as an organic catalyst in the Nef reaction [15] and C-N cross-coupling reaction [16]. DBU is acting as a base and deprotonating agent. In addition to this, DBU also acts as a nucleophile and non-nucleophilic base in many organic transformations in recent years [17–20]. Li et al. reported an efficient C-N bond formation of active methylene with α-diazocarbonyls in the presence of DBU [21]. They suggested that DBU as a nucleophile activates the methylene group and N-terminal of α-diazocarbonyls to afford electrophilic intermediate which initiates C-N bond formation. Biginelli reaction is one of the prime MCRs that involves the condensation of aldehydes, dicarbonyl compound, and urea or thiourea in a single step [22], leading to the synthesis of dihydropyrimidinones (DHPMs). The end products of Biginelli reaction, DHPMs, are important biomaterials in pharmaceutical industry and are extensively used as calcium channel blockers [23] and antihypertensive agents [24], and also, they have been reported to possess antibacterial [25], anticancer [26], anti-inflammatory [27] antidiabetic [28], anti-SARS-CoV-2 activity [29] and anti- HIV activity [30]. There are several reports of DHPM synthesis using IL as catalysts in Biginelli reaction under homogenous or heterogeneous conditions [31a–d]. In two separate studies, [MImH]OAc [32] and [BCMIm]Cl [33], ILs have been reported to catalyze the Biginelli reaction with quite high efficiency and selectivity. In the former case, the authors reported that refluxing the reaction mixture in the presence of [MImH]OAc at 100 °C yielded 83% of the DHPMs. In the latter, 96% yield of the DHPM product was isolated in the [BCMIm]Cl catalyzed Biginelli reaction carried out at 80 °C for 15–25 min. Although the methods served well in achieving higher yields of the DHPM products avoiding the use of external solvents, they suffered from drawbacks like the use of corrosive mineral acids in the preparation of the protic [BCMIM][Cl] IL catalysts and longer durations involved in their synthesis. To the best of our knowledge, no reports of Biginelli synthesis in the presence of [DBUH]+[MIm]− protic ILs have been published. We demonstrate herein for the first time the use of [DBUH]+[MIm]− ILs in the Biginelli reaction to synthesize cinnamaldehyde-based dihydropyrimidinone (DHPM) derivatives. The DBU-MIm coupled ILs have been synthesized by the abstraction of N-H proton of imidazolium moiety by DBU base as described by Zhu et al. [34]. The as-prepared ILs have been employed in the Biginelli reaction. The present work presents an environment-benign synthetic procedure for DHPMs with advantages like high product yields, a simple-to-recover and reusable catalyst, and the absence of toxic solvents. Results and discussion Synthesis of the catalyst Initially, the catalyst to be used in the Biginelli reaction i.e. [DBUH]+[Im]− ILs were obtained by neutralization reaction between the superbase DBU (1) and imidazole or methyl-substituted imidazole (2) at 60–70 °C [34] as per Scheme 1. The superbase DBU abstracts the proton of the imidazole moiety to form the corresponding protic [DBUH]+[Im]− ILs 3a-c. The formation of the ILs 3a-c was preliminarily indicated by a change of solution color from transparent to yellow. Furthermore, comparative FTIR and 1H NMR analyses of imidazole, DBU, and the IL have validated their formation (Figs. 1 and 2 ). Fig. 1 depicts the FTIR spectrum for imidazoles, DBU, and all synthesized ILs. The multiple peaks beyond 3000 cm−1 corresponding to the H-bonded amine group present in the FTIR spectrum of imidazole ( Fig. 1b) vanished in the FTIR spectrum of resulting IL 3a (Fig. 1e), whereas all of the peaks corresponding to DBU IR stretching were retained (Fig. 1a). Similar peak shifting was observed in the FTIR spectrum of the 1-MIm and 2-MIm coupled ILs (Fig. 1f and g) in comparison to their parent compounds (Fig. 1c and d). The shifting of the signal at δ 12.9, corresponding to N-H proton of the pure imidazole to δ 5.8 in the 1H NMR spectrum of [DBUH]+[2-MIm]− (Fig. 2), confirms the proton exchange between the DBU and Im moieties. The other DBU and Im protons appear at their usual positions in the 1H NMR spectrum. However, no noteworthy difference was observed in the 13C NMR spectra of the two compounds (Figs. S3 and S6). On a similar note, the signal due to exchanged N-H proton i.e. proton of [DBU-H]+ moiety appeared at δ 4.7 and δ 3.9 in the 1H NMR spectrum of IL-3a (Fig. S2) and IL-3b (Fig. S5), respectively. All the ILs could be obtained in an interval of 2–2.5 h upon refluxing the contents at a mild temperature of 60–70 °C (Table 1 ). The IR and NMR spectra of the synthesized ILs 3a-c is provided in Figs. S1–S9. Catalytic studies of [DBUH]+[Im]− ILs in the synthesis of DHPMs The catalytic behavior of [DBUH]+[Im]− ILs was assessed in the Biginelli reaction for the synthesis of DHPMs. As Im and DBU-based ILs have already been reported to catalyze Biginelli reaction in an efficient manner [20,35], a model Biginelli reaction of cinnamaldehyde, acetylacetone, and urea was carried out separately in the presence of the 10 mol% each of DBU, MIm and the [DBUH]+[2-MIm]− IL as per Scheme 2 and the results are summarized in Table 2 . It has been found that when 10 mol% of DBU alone was used as a catalyst, a moderate yield of 59% of DHPMs was obtained in 45 min upon refluxing at 90 °C (Table 2, entry 1). And only 47% of the product (Table 2, entry 2) could be isolated in the presence of 10 mol% of imidazole as a catalyst under similar conditions. But the use of [DBUH]+[Im]− IL in the same model reaction resulted in an excellent yield of DHPM (80%) of the target product in an interval of 45 min (Table 2, entry 3, 5,7). The other two ILs i.e. 1-MIm and 2-MIm coupled DBU ILs afforded respectively, 87% and 91% of the DHPM product under similar reaction conditions. These findings suggested that the DBU-Im combination catalyzed the Biginelli reaction in a synergic manner. The 2-MIm coupled DBU IL provided the best catalytic results among the various ILs used. The synergic role of the [DBUH]+[2-MIm]− IL has been established using DFT studies and explained under the heading mechanistic studies. Optimization of reaction conditions for the synthesis of DHPMs The conditions were optimized by running the model reaction at various temperatures and with different amounts of catalyst. Only a trace amount of DHPMs could be obtained at room temperature in the presence of 10 mol% of [DBUH]+[Im]− IL catalyst (Table 3 , entries 2–4). Increased reaction temperature resulted in higher yields of DHPM (Table 3, entries 8–10). However, increasing the catalytic dosage didn't result in a significant increase in product yield (Table 3, entries 10 and 11). The Biginelli reaction was found to be best catalyzed by the [DBUH]+[2-MIm]− IL, with a maximum of 91 percent of DHPM product isolated at 90 °C with 10 mol% of the catalyst in 45 min (Table 3, entry 10). The observed catalytic activity among imidazole ILs was found to be in the order 2-MIm>1-MIm>Im (Table 3, entries 8–10), which may be attributed to the nucleophilic strength of the anionic part of the DBU-Im coupled ILs. In comparison to the non-substituted imidazolide anion, the methyl-substituted imidazolide anions are stronger nucleophiles. Thus, 10 mol% of [DBUH]+[2-MIm]− catalytic dosage, a temperature of 90 °C, and a duration of 45 min were chosen for further experimentation. Synthesis of DHPMs in different solvent systems Further, to evaluate the influence of polar solvents, the same model reaction was carried out in the presence of ethanol, acetonitrile, water, dichloromethane, and toluene and the results are summed up in Table 4 . It was found that with 10 mol% of catalyst, a maximum of 59%, 45%, and 30% (Table 4, Entries 3,5,7) of DHPM product was yielded in ethanol, acetonitrile, and water, respectively, under refluxing conditions when the reaction continued overnight. The poor yields obtained in presence of polar solvents may be attributed to the solvation of the cationic and anionic parts of the IL catalyst which impairs their catalytic behavior. However, the use of non-polar solvents had little or no effect on the yields of the DHPM products in the DBU-Im catalyzed Biginelli reaction (Table 4, Entries 8–11). Notably, the yield of the DHPM under solvent-less conditions was also found to be as high as 91% in 45 min (Table 4, entry 1). Thus, solvent-less conditions were chosen for further synthesis of DHPM derivatives reacting cinnamaldehyde with a variety of aldehydic substrates and urea or thiourea. Synthesis of cinnamaldehyde based DHPMs and their thione analogs The study is now extended to the synthesis of a series of cinnamaldehyde-based DHPMs. Under the optimized reaction conditions and with 10 mol% of the [DBUH]+[2-MIm]− catalyst, cinnamaldehyde condensed with urea/thiourea and acetylacetone/ethyl acetoacetate to give rise to the corresponding products in high to excellent yields (Table 5 ). The reaction of cinnamaldehyde and urea with acetylacetone and ethyl acetoacetate afforded 89% (Table 5, Entry 1) and 84% (Table 5, Entry 3) of the DHPM product. The yield of the thione analogs was also found to be high (Table 5, Entry 2 and 4). Melting points observed for the synthesized DHPMs and thiones matched with that reported in the literature. Further, the formation of products 7a-i has been validated by their 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectral analysis (Figs. S10–S39). Mechanistic studies As the Biginelli reaction involves a polar intermediate, the [DBUH]+[Im]− protic ILs have been found to catalyze the same. The IL catalyst lowers the activation barrier and leads to the easy formation of the DHPM product [36]. The proposed mechanism is shown in Fig. 3 . In one of the mechanisms reported for the Biginelli reaction, the aldehyde and urea condense initially to provide the iminium ion intermediate which further combines with a ketone and cyclizes to afford the final DHPM product. By H-bonding interactions, the [DBUH]+ counterpart of the IL catalyst used in the current methodology appears to boost the nucleophilicity of the carbonyl carbon, whereas the [2-MIm]− anion aids in increasing the negative charge density on the nitrogen of urea by abstracting its proton. On a similar note, imidazole anion [MIm]− abstracts hydrogen from the CH2 group of acetylacetone and assisted its attack onto the imine bond resulting in the formation of cyclized DHPM product as shown in Fig. 3. The neutralized DBU and MIm species interacted meanwhile to regenerate the IL catalyst. The proposed mechanism was also put to test using DFT studies. It was observed that the proposed mechanism holds good with DFT studies. The optimized structure of [DBUH]+[2-MIm]− is shown in Fig. 4 a. The energies for the DBU and 2-MIm components decreased considerably from −462 Hartree and −266 Hartree to −728 Hartree during the formation of [DBUH]+[2-MIm]− coupled IL. The energy results also authenticated the hydrogen-bonding interactions between the two components of IL moiety. Availability of HOMO on [2-MIm]− and LUMO on [DBUH]+ (Fig. 4b and c) also indicates the transfer of charge between the two. DFT studies have further helped in strengthening the idea that ionic liquid formed is acting as a catalyst in bringing the two components of the complex together to form a Schiff base (Fig. 5 a), with considerable lowering in energy to approximately −1376 Hartree. The ionic liquid comes in perfect sync to incorporate the final piece of the complex to the Schiff base formed earlier with final optimized energy of −841 Hartree approx. (Fig. 5b). Comparative catalytic studies of different ILs in Biginelli reaction Finally, the results of the present protocol were compared with those reported in the presence of other ILs. The new method produced good to exceptional yields of cinnamaldehyde DHPMs that were comparable to those achieved with previously published ILs (Table 6 ). With 10 mol% of DBU-2MIm coupled IL catalyst, a maximum of 82–91% of product yields were achieved in 45 min at 90 °C. The procedure avoids the use of solvents and the requirement of specialized reaction conditions like in a few cases (Table 6, Entries 1 and 5). Thus, the present protocol for Biginelli synthesis of DHPMs is simple, efficient, and reproducible. Recyclization and reusability of the [DBUH]+[2-MIm]− IL The [DBUH]+[2-MIm]− IL catalyst recovered after extraction of the DHPM product in ethyl acetate layer was vacuum dried prior to its use for the next run. The recovered IL catalyst was employed for 4 consecutive runs, in the Biginelli reaction of cinnamaldehyde with urea and acetylacetone, to explore its reusability. The DHPM product yield was found to decrease slightly (Fig. 6 a) owing to a little loss in the amount of recovered catalyst after each run (Fig. 6b). However, the retention of all the peaks from the fresh IL catalyst in the FTIR spectra of the recycled catalyst (Fig. 7 ) confirms the stability of the DBU-MIm IL catalyst during the reaction course and established it as a reusable material. The stability of the IL catalyst has also been established on the basis of TGA analysis (Fig. S10). Conclusion In summary, a new class of DBU-Im coupled ionic liquids have been developed as an efficient and reusable catalyst in the Biginelli reaction. The catalysts have been found to generate the dihydropyrimidinone product under much milder conditions. Among the various DBU-Im coupled ILs, the [DBUH]+[2-MIm]− IL showed the best catalytic performance which was attributed to its greater nucleophilicity. DFT studies reveal the synergic role of the cationic and anionic parts of the [DBUH]+[MIm]− ILs under study. The IL assists in the easy formation of the Schiff base and further its cyclization with 1,3-diketone to give DHPM as the final product. The DBU-Im coupled ILs could be easily recovered and reused. Our findings establish the DBU-Im coupled ILs catalyzed Biginelli reaction to be efficient, solvent-less, and greener routes to produce DHPMs. Experimental General Chemicals used in the synthesis were purchased from Sigma Aldrich, Spectrochem, and CDH. Monitoring of the chemical reactions was done using thin-layer chromatography (TLC). TLC plates were developed by coating glass plates with silica gel in chloroform. Marking of the spot was done using capillary tubes. The spot was detected using an iodine chamber. A 3:2 mixture of hexane and ethyl acetate was used to elute the compounds. Melting points were determined using the open capillary method. Final identification of the products was done using FTIR, 1H NMR, and 13C NMR spectral techniques. The 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance Neo 500 MHz spectrometer using CDCl3 and DMSO-d6 as solvents, and TMS as an internal standard. Chemical shifts are reported in δ values. The FTIR spectra of the compounds were recorded using a Bruker Alpha FTIR spectrophotometer. Theoretical studies were performed using the DMol3 package with GGA-DFT, using double numerical plus polarization (DNP) as a basic set [37a-b]. All electrons of the system were treated with B3LYP [38a–c] local functions for the exchange-correlation potential. General procedure for the synthesis of [DBUH]+[2-MIm]− ILs The synthesis of DBU-Im coupled ILs has been carried out by a neutralization reaction between superbase DBU and the imidazole derivatives [34]. In a typical reaction, equimolar amounts of DBU and imidazole were mixed in a 100 ml round bottom flask (RBF) and stirred for 2–3 h at 60–70 °C using a magnetic stirrer. Meanwhile, the color of the solution turned yellow. Then, the excess ethyl acetate was evaporated to obtain the desired ionic liquid. Ionic liquid yield was calculated by following the solvent extraction method was used for recovery and yield of ionic liquid [31f]. Silver nitrate tests were performed to ensure complete removal of metal halide salts. The remaining water content in ILs was detected by Karl Fischer method [31f]. General procedure for the synthesis of DHPMs All the reactions were conducted in a single-necked 100 mL RBF equipped with a magnetic stirrer. In a typical reaction, aldehyde (10 mmol), acetylacetone (10 mmol), and urea (12 mmol) were taken in an oven-dried 100 ml RBF. To this mixture 10 mol% of the DBU-Im coupled IL catalyst was added and the contents of the RBF were refluxed at 90 °C for 45 min using a magnetic stirrer. After the completion of the reaction as judged by TLC, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature. The contents were then poured into a beaker containing 100 mL ice-cold water. A yellow solid got precipitated out, which was filtered through suction. The IL was recovered from the aqueous filtrate by solvent extraction with chloroform. The yellow precipitates of the DHPM product were recrystallized out of hot ethanol. coredata.dc:description: In present work, the application of a novel set of 1,8-Diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene (DBU) and methylimidazole (MIm) coupled ionic liquids (ILs) in the Biginelli reaction has been investigated. In the modified Biginelli reaction, cinnamaldehyde, urea, and 1,3-diketone condensed in the presence of 10 mol% of the DBU-MIm coupled IL catalyst at 90 °C to afford dihydropyrimidinones in high to excellent yields in 45 min. Additionally, the effect of temperature, catalytic amount, and solvent has also been unfolded. The reaction has been found to the follow iminium ion mechanism and the synergic role played by the [DBUH]+ and [MIm]− moieties has been established by DFT calculations. The easy post-procedure recovery and reusability of the DBU-MIm IL catalysts make the present protocol of Biginelli synthesis simple, benign and reproducible.
coredata.dc:title: DBU-MIm coupled ionic liquids as reusable catalysts for the Biginelli reaction
